response.answer_text: Almost every Upanishad is a unique piece of spiritual science and a simple version of the hidden wisdom of Vedas, the oldest surviving scriptures of the world. As a Spiritual Scientist, let me take the question as a golden opportunity to represent the real scientific beauty of Vedas, Upanishads, Brahm Sutra, Holy Gita, Tantra Vidya, and Yogasutra in an integrated and sequential form of Akhand Sutra, Integrating Thread of Nature. According to Akhand Sutra, the sequence could be, Perfect and Integrated Universal Consciousness: 1. Brhad-Aranyaka Upanishad (V.1.1), “Purnam Adah, purnam idam, purnai purnam udacyate, Purnasya purnam addaya purnam evavasisyate” That is full; this is full, from fullness proceeds fullness. If we take away fullness from fullness, fullness still remains. It means that every manifestation of Nature is indestructible, in-exhaustible, irreducible, perfect, vast, and complete. It means that the sum of everything in the universe is constant. Purnam could also be represented as Akhand, which means integration and integrated. This above verse made me realize the real meaning and significance of the following very important spiritual statements of Vedas and Upanishads, 1. “Tat-Tvam-Asi” means that everything (Tvam) in the universe is identical (Asi). 2. “Eko-ham-bahusayam” means that every object of Nature has come from one source. 3. “Aham-Brahmasmi” means that every human being is created with a divine design. The Essence: A perfect, single, and ultimate Divine Constant of Nature is hidden in the above verses. The Origin and Unmanifested Source: Primordial Space (Akash) According to Akhand Sutra, the ultimate, formless, omnipotent, omniscient, omnipresent, and all-pervasive Universal Consciousness is called Nirakar-Nirgun-Brahman (God-Nature-Paramatma) and it is the source of everything in the universe and Nature. Before the Creation of Cosmos: Darkness and Inertia (Tamas) Vedas: Before the creation of the cosmos, the Primordial Cosmos (Akash) was filled with darkness (Andhakar) and everything in the cosmos was in a state of inertia (Tamas). Brhad-Aranyaka Upanishad (I.2.1), “Naivecha Kimcanagra Asit, Mrityunaivedam Avrtam Asit!” There was nothing in the Primordial Space in the beginning. It was indeed covered by death (Mrityu). The verse reinforces the above message of Vedas. The concept of Blackhole of Dark matter is also hidden in the verse. Now, let us contemplate on the above concepts. Can anything come out of nothing? Nothing can come out of nothing. This is an eternal Law of Nature. Hence, there was something in the Primordial Space, which was in a state of darkness, inertia, and death. What was it? A New Hypothesis: Isomers of Neon-21 The above three profound statements of Vedas and Upanishads made me recognize, conceive, and reveal that the Primordial Space was filled with the isomers of Neon-21. Now, let us study, understand, appreciate, and apply the concept of the above hypothesis. Neon element is an inert matter. Neon forms a stable noble gas. The isomers of Neon-21 contain 10 protons, 11 neutrons, and 10 electrons. Neon is smaller than the preceeding elements of the second period of the Periodic Table. The ten electrons of Neon-21 are fully focused towards the center (protons and neutrons). As a result, there is darkness outside. The Scientific Proof: Neon Sign Boards do not exhibit any light until they are charged with electricity. The Essence: The ancient Indian description of the inherent attributes of the Soul (Atma-Atman) and the inert matter, like Helium Atoms or Neon Atoms is identical in every way. Is the phonetic resemblance of Atom and Atma a mere coincidence? Now, let us comprehend the science of five elements of Nature. The First Manifestation: Five Basic Elements – Panch-Bhutas The energy, after losing heat, produced the five elements (Panch-Bhuta). The five elements are made of the following, 1. Akash-Bhuta: Quintessence. It is responsible for sound vibrations and hearing. 2. Vayu-Bhuta: Air Element. It is responsible for touch sensation. 3. Agni-Bhuta: Fire Element. It is responsible for heat, light vibrations, and vision. 4. Apa-Bhuta: Water Element. It is responsible for the liquid taste sensation. 5. Prithvi-Bhuta: Earth. It is responsible for smelling sensation. The First Representation: Maha Brahmand – Macrocosmic Universe. The Spiral Galaxy of Milky Way is an integral part of Maha Brahmand, the Greater Universe. The Second Manifestation: The Microcosmic Universe: Solar system – Brahmand: Our Solar system is considered the microcosmic representation of the macrocosmic universe. Now, let us comprehend the science of three major manifestations of Nature. Brhad-Aranyaka Upanishad (I.5.16), “Atha trayo vaha lokah, manusya-lokah, pitr-lokah, deva-lokah iti” “Let there be three worlds, the world of humans (earth), the world of ancestors (intermediate sphere), and the world of gods (heaven)”. It means that our Solar system is made of three parts; earth, atmosphere, and planets. It also means that every created object of Nature is made of the three major parts. The Scientific Proof: Three parts of the Cell. Under the compound microscope, we see only three parts of the cell; cell membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus. The Essence: The three debts of human birth and life in the service of earth, ancestors and divine beings and the three integral components of Divyank, the Divine Constant, are reflected in the verse. Now, let us explore, enumerate, and explain another important Upanishad. Chandogya Upanishad (VIII.7.1), “Ya atma apahata-papma vijaro vimrtyur visoko vijighasto'pipasah satya-kamah satya-samkalpa, so'nvestavyah, so vijijnanasi-tavyah sa sarvams ca lokan apnoti sarvams ca Kaman, yas tam atmanam anuvidya vijnati; iti ha prajapatir uvaca”. “Self, which is free from evil, free from old age, free from death, free from grief, free from hunger, and free from thirst, and whose desire is real, whose thought is real, that Self should be sought, desired, and understood. A person, who knows and understands that Self, obtains all worlds and all desires”. This is the essence of the spiritual preaching of Prajapati (The Lord of Public-Brahma). Indra (King of Gods) and Virochana (King of Demons), who heard Prajapati giving the above sermon, were fully impressed with his discourse. Indra and Virochana were curious and wanted to learn more about the Self. Hence, they approached Prajapati. Prajapati asked them to become students and stay in his hermit (ashram) as celibates (Brahmacharis) for thirty-two years. In the end, Prajapati explained to them about the importance of physical health, wealth, and the waking (Jagrat) consciousness. Both were impressed and happily left for their respective abodes. Virochana was fully satisfied. He, in turn, explained the beauty and importance of physical health, abundance of wealth, and gratification of physical desires and pleasures to the demons. In fact, this advice is strictly followed by the majority of people even today. Indra doubted the eternal beauty of the perishable body and came back. Indra was asked to stay in hermit for another thirty-two years. He was then taught about the dreaming (Swapna) consciousness. He was impressed and went away but before reaching heaven, he realized the futility of dreaming consciousness too. He returned. Indra was asked to stay for another thirty-two years. He was then taught about the deep-sleep (Sisupta) consciousness. Indra went with tranquil heart and mind but shortly realized that in this state of deep sleep consciousness he is not aware of “His True Self”. He came back again. Then Prajapati asked him to live with him for just five years. Before the end of five years, Prajapati explained the nature of Soul, which is beyond dualities and death, and reaches the highest state of enlightenment in his own True form, the Supreme consciousness, called Turiya, which is eternally in tune with the Ultimate Soul/Self. What is the hidden Wisdom? The total time spent by Indra is 101 years (32+32+32+5=101). Let us consider that thirty-two years are equal to seven parts. Then, one part will be equal to 4.57 (32/7=4.57) years. I suppose, 4.57 years were expressed as 5 years, for convenience. The Essence: Pi (22/7): The three phases of thirty-two years each represent 21 (3x7) parts. The last phase of 5 years represents the twenty-second part. The total period of 101 years represents the numeral value of Pi (22/7). 1. The number, 22/7 represents Pi, one of the most important natural mathematical concepts. 2. Pi is used to calculate the circumference of a circle, the symbol of space (Akash). Chandogya Upanishad (II.10.5), “Eka-Vimsaty Adityam Apnoti, Eka-Vimso Va Ito'sav Adityo!” 21 (Eka-vimsaty) stages of the Solar system can be measured with 21 steps. The Essence: It means that the three major parts of the Solar system are made of 21 parts. Chandogya Upanishad (II.10.5), “Dva-vimsena param adityaj jayate; tan nakam, tad visokam!!” With 22 (Dva-vimsena) steps, one conquers the world beyond the Sun, where there is absolute bliss without any sorrow. The Scientific Message – The First Stage of Creation – 22/21: During the first stage of creation, the 21 parts of the cell with the division of one centriole into two centrioles and the total number of parts of the cell become 22 parts. Chandogya Upanishad (II.10.6), “Apnoti Hadityasya Jayam, Paro Hasyaditya-Jayati Jayo Bhavati, ya Etad Evam Vidvan Atma-Sammitam Ati-Mrityu Sapta-Vidham Samopaste, Sampaste”. Knowing this, the wise and enlightened Soul obtains an eternal victory over the Sun. He obtains still higher victory over death (Atimrityu) when he meditates on the sevenfold (Sapta) knowledge (Vidham). This verse implies that there are seven parts in every aspect of Nature. The Essence: The Significance of Number Seven. According to Akhand Sutra, the three independent parts of the Solar system, namely, the earth, the atmosphere of earth, and heaven are also made of seven parts each. Now, let us explore, enumerate, and explain the application of number seven in Nature. Sat-Chakra-Nirupana: 7 Chakras. According to Sat-Chakra-Nirupana, there are 7 major Chakras, namely, Muladhara, Svadhisthana, Nabhi, Anahata, Visudhi, Ajna, and Sahasrara, in the human body. Maha Gayatri Mantra: 7 Maha Vyahritis. Maha Gayatri Mantra from Maha Narayani Upanishad has 7 Vyahritis, which represent the 7 Chakras of the human body. The shape of Kundalini – Pi - 22/7: According to Sat-Chakra-Nirupana, the shape of Kundalini is Trivakrit, which means that there are three-plus coils and they are represented as 22/7 or 31/7. Pi (22/7) and the First Stage of Creation (22/21): This concept reinforces that every aspect of Nature is made of 3 sub-parts. The Conclusion: For various reasons, we observe that the prime emphasis was more on the sequence of one, three, seven, twenty-one, and twenty-two numbers in the ancient Indian documents. Now, let us do contemplative meditation on one important section of Aitreya Upanishad. Aitareya Upanishad (Chapter 1): The Essence: 1. In the beginning, there was only Self (Atma) and nothing else in the world. 2. The Self-created three worlds; the heaven, atmosphere and the earth. 3. From the water, the Self drew forth Lok-Palan, the Guardian of the world or Cosmic Person. 4. The Self carved the Mouth, Nostrils, Eyes, Ears, Skin, Heart, Navel and the reproductive organ in the Cosmic Person. 5. The Self-created food for the Cosmic Person from the Primordial Ocean water. 6. Then, the Cosmic Person was subjected to hunger and thirst. 7. The Cosmic Person sought the food with Speech (Mouth), Breath (Nostrils), Sight (Eyes), Hearing (Ears), Touch (Skin), Mind (Heart) and the reproductive organ respectively. 8. The Cosmic Person was unable to catch the food with the above seven vital organs and eat. 9. There is absolutely no confusion up to this stage of the story. 10. The other associated knowledge has also been explained in the light of modern sciences. Aitareya Upanishad (I.3.10), “Tad Apanenajidghrksat, Tad Avayat!” Then, the cosmic person sought to seize it (the food) by the Apana, the out-breath/the outlet and he was successful in getting the food. The Essence: It means that the food was received through Apana, an outlet. How can we receive food through an outlet? The commentators of Aitreya Upanishad have acknowledged their failure to explain the above verse. No wonder, the above verse is considered one of the greatest mysteries of Upanishads. As a result, many people call Vedas and Upanishads as blabbering of an infancy civilization. To comprehend the hidden wisdom of Vedas and Upanishads, we have to be in tune with the Universal Consciousness and the consciousness of the Sages, who compiled and composed Vedas and Upanishads. Now, let us comprehend the real meaning of Apana, the outlet. Panch-Pranas: 1. Big Question! How can an outlet become an inlet and seize the food? In reality, the Sage Aitreya is talking of a growing fetus in the mother’s womb. Let us change the perspective and see a new picture. New Perspective: 1.
